EDITORIAL OBSERVER: WHEN DOGS ARE MORE IMPORTANT THAN PEOPLE 

  By   BRENT STAPLES   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service  
  I moved to Brooklyn 15 years ago and have since spent several
mornings each week walking, running or just greeting the day in
Prospect Park. In recent years, these tranquil mornings have been
too often disrupted by snarling dogs who are permitted off their
leashes in the early morning during what the park system refers to
as ``courtesy hours.'' In the last year alone, I have been cornered
four times by ill-behaved dogs _ two of them pit bulls _ who were
clearly unfit to run loose in a public park.

   The owners of such dogs rarely apologize and sometimes behave as
belligerently as their animals. The owner of a big, menacing boxer
promised to kill me when I told him I would mace the dog if it
charged me again. A few weeks later, the owner of a frothing German
shepherd declined to leash his dog _ essentially using it to corner
me, while he advised me to stay home during ``courtesy hours'' and
lectured me on the dog's right to be free.

   Dog groups in Brooklyn and elsewhere are fighting to head off
new dog regulations and to preserve the privileges they now enjoy
in the public parks. But those privileges will remain at risk
unless the owners can learn to balance the needs of their animals
with the needs of the human beings with whom they share New York
City's public spaces.

   Animal welfare officials estimate that there are a million dogs
in the city _ or roughly one canine for every eight human beings.
The number of dogs will continue to grow, thanks to new federal
regulations that allow the 430,000 people who live in New York City
public housing to own dogs. In 1998, the chairman of the New York
City Housing Authority tried to block the measure, arguing that
public housing's dog problem was already out of control, even with
rules that limited dog ownership to the elderly and the disabled.

   Over the last 10 years, the number of dog bites reported to the
City Health Department has ranged from 6,000 to nearly 11,000 a
year. The number of biting dogs taken into custody by animal care
officials grew by nearly a third between 1996 and 1999, as more and
more New Yorkers who were ill prepared to train and handle such
dogs acquired them anyway. Testifying before the City Council last
year, the city's health commissioner, Dr. Neal Cohen, concluded
that New York had ``failed to adequately protect the public from
biting dogs.'' Cohen supported a Giuliani administration bill that
would have required liability insurance for pit bulls _ which are
responsible for about a third of all bites in the city _ and made
it easier for the city to confiscate vicious and biting dogs
generally. Dog groups have blocked the bill.

   The practice of allowing dogs to run free in city parks during
the early morning and late evening evolved informally during the
1970s and 80s, when the parks were suffering from neglect and dog
owners felt safer than other people about entering the overgrown,
crime-ridden spaces. The ``courtesy hours'' continued after the
parks were cleaned up and patrons returned. But the last few years
have seen considerable friction between dog owners and park
visitors who want to picnic, sunbathe or exercise without being set
upon by wayward animals.

   With too few park officers to cover all the boroughs, city park
authorities rely on loosely organized groups of dog owners who use
peer pressure to bring owners into line. Conscientious dog owners
routinely chase down others who break park rules and fail to clean
up after their dogs. But, fearing that poorly behaved dogs will be
euthanized, dog owners sometimes suppress news of even serious
maulings that should be reported to the police.

   In September 1999, a Brooklyn woman named Sarah Lowe was badly
bitten by a dog that was part pit bull and roaming off its leash in
Prospect Park. The dog clamped down so fiercely that it fractured
Lowe's wrist. After six months of physical therapy, Lowe may yet
require surgery to correct the damage.

   A dog that breaks the bones of an adult could kill a small
child. But instead of filing a police complaint right away, Lowe
says she negotiated with the dog's owner, who agreed to muzzle the
dog. Lowe waited two months before she reported the attack to the
police _ and said she did so only after finding that the dog had
bitten someone else and was still roaming the park unmuzzled.

   The dog that bit Lowe is listed in the police report as a pit
bull mix named Ozzie. But as recently as two weeks ago, I
encountered this dog bounding through the park playing fetch, as
wary walkers moved aside. A man walking his own dog warned: ``Keep
out of his way. That is one dangerous animal.''

   The police and the health department hold the ultimate
responsibility for controlling dogs proved to be vicious. But if
owners wish to keep their privileges in the parks, they will need
to show as much concern for public comfort and safety as for the
rights of their animals.
